conclusion: Determine the speed of the sphere at point C and the tension in the string at that point.
The sphere is at rest at point A, forming an angle θ = 30° with the vertical.
Forces acting on the sphere are gravity and electric force.
Components of gravitational and electric forces along the string must balance.
mg cos θ = qE sin θ
E = (mg √3)/q
Sphere moves under gravity and electric field from point B to C.
Change in gravitational potential energy from B to C is -mgL.
Change in electric potential energy from B to C is -qEL.
Total change in potential energy is -mgL(1 + √3).
By conservation of energy, kinetic energy at point C is mgL(1 + √3).
At point C, forces are tension T, gravitational force mg, and electric force qE.
Centripetal force is 2mg(1 + √3).
Vertical component of tension balances gravitational force and vertical component of centripetal force.
Horizontal component of tension balances electric force and horizontal component of centripetal force.
Tension in the string at point C is mg(3 + 2√3).
Speed of the sphere at point C is √(2gL(1 + √3)).
Tension in the string at point C is mg(3 + 2√3).
